content: oh my god he's making a wash I don't know what that means I just started
painting why am i washing my terrain little friends fellow crafters at your
boy pillow pal here with another episode of black magic crafts last episode I
showed you guys how to make basic dungeon tiles a great beginner project
and just like I hoped the feedback was overwhelmingly positive
I received a ton of messages and comments from people telling me that it
was the first project they ever tried while the response to the project was
overwhelmingly positive I did have one reoccurring comment or question that
kept coming up a lot of people were a little bit confused by the stage where I
did the black wash I took for granted that some of you may have never done any
terrain or model painting in the past and may not be familiar with washes what
the hell are they well basically they're just really watered down paint you apply
it over a project to allow some of the dark pigment to get into all the nooks
and crannies cracks and crevices of a piece to help bring a lot of depth to it
the wash in combination with a highlighting dry brush adds a lot of
realism and a lot of depth to even a simple paint job it also helps to
weather a peace making it look like it wasn't freshly painted it gives it that
bit of earthy grimy feel there are a lot of different ways you can make washes
but what I'm going to show you is the way I do it which is literally the
cheapest and easiest way you can do it you may not be it's definitely not the
best way to do it but it's simple it's effective and you can make a large batch
of it for basically no cost which is exactly what you want when using it on a
lot of terrain pieces if you have water a little bit of acrylic craft paint dish
soap and a container you're ready to make a wash so let's mix up a batch so
you can see what I'm talking about fill a small resealable container with
water pour in approximately half a teaspoon of black acrylic craft paint
you don't need to be too exact with this as you can just keep adding paint or
water until you're happy with the consistency
I mix it thoroughly you should see the pigments start to transfer to whatever
you are using to mix here I can see that I need it a bit more black so I just
added a few more drops and kept mixing you can test out the wash and some paper
towel it should definitely make a fairly dark stain I find that a black wash
looks better if you also add some other color to it to make it look more dirty I
tend to add a little bit of dark brown and a bit of a Foresti green you really
don't have to be too worried about how much you put in just add a little bit at
a time and test it out as you go you can always add more paint or water to get it
right but really you can be very relaxed about your amounts the thing that makes
a wash work much better than just watered down paint is some sort of flow
aid this helps the wash run into all the
little details of the piece and roll off of the high spots there are many
different substances you can use for this but the easiest is just to grab
your dish soap from the kitchen and put in a drop of that once it's all mixed up
test it out on a piece of train if you think that it's too dark then add more
water if you think that's not dark enough just add a little bit more black
paint again you don't have to worry too much about your consistencies just play
with some test pieces until you get the look you want keep in mind that as the
wash dries it will lighten up a bit and flow away from the high spots once
you've done this a few times you will realize it's not really a big deal and
get comfortable improvising your mix ratio there you go now you know how to
make a cheap and simple block wash or your terrain pieces I hope you found
this helpful if you did hit the like button leave me a comment if you aren't
